articles.headline: 13 Men, and No Women, Are Writing New G.O.P. Health Bill in Senate
articles.snippet: The Republicans working on a bill to replace much of the Affordable Care Act do not include a woman or the moderates who could determine its fate.
articles.abstract: The Republicans working on a bill to replace much of the Affordable Care Act do not include a woman or the moderates who could determine its fate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top Republican in the Senate, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, has a reputation as a shrewd tactician and a wily strategist — far more than his younger counterpart in the House, Speaker Paul D. Ryan.

articles.headline: Forget Taxes, Warren Buffett Says. The Real Problem Is Health Care.
articles.snippet: Over the weekend, Mr. Buffett urged fellow executives to start worrying about rising health care costs and how they put American businesses at a disadvantage.
articles.abstract: Over the weekend, Mr. Buffett urged fellow executives to start worrying about rising health care costs and how they put American businesses at a disadvantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: OMAHA — “The tax system is not crippling our business around the world.”

articles.headline: Express Scripts to Offer Cheaper Drugs for Uninsured Customers
articles.snippet: InsideRx, a free program, should lower medication costs on about 40 common prescriptions for some patients.
articles.abstract: InsideRx, a free program, should lower medication costs on about 40 common prescriptions for some patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is one of the most acute indignities of being uninsured in this country: Those with the least ability to pay are asked to spend the most for their prescription drugs.

articles.headline: Sinclair Unveils Tribune Deal, Raising Worries It Will Be Too Powerful
articles.snippet: After Sinclair said it had agreed to buy Tribune Media for $3.9 billion, some pointed out it had shown a willingness to use its TV stations to advance a conservative agenda.
articles.abstract: After Sinclair said it had agreed to buy Tribune Media for $3.9 billion, some pointed out it had shown a willingness to use its TV stations to advance a conservative agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an era of information saturation, when cable news seems ubiquitous and Twitter posts stream forth uninterrupted, local television still holds a powerful grip on the American consciousness. And the Sinclair Broadcast Group just tightened its grasp.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Sally Yates Tells Senators She Warned Trump About Michael Flynn
articles.snippet: Ms. Yates, the former acting attorney general, gave a dramatic account of an unfolding crisis in the early days of President Trump’s White House.
articles.abstract: Ms. Yates, the former acting attorney general, gave a dramatic account of an unfolding crisis in the early days of President Trump’s White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Less than a week into the Trump administration, Sally Q. Yates, the acting attorney general, hurried to the White House with an urgent concern. The president’s national security adviser, she said, had lied to the vice president about his Russian contacts and was vulnerable to blackmail by Moscow.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Emmarie Huetteman

articles.headline: Kushner Family Stands to Gain From Visa Rules in Trump’s First Major Law
articles.snippet: A marketing campaign by Kushner Companies, tied to a visa program recently renewed by the president, has raised more ethical quandaries in Washington.
articles.abstract: A marketing campaign by Kushner Companies, tied to a visa program recently renewed by the president, has raised more ethical quandaries in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was the first major piece of legislation that President Trump signed into law, and buried on Page 734 was one sentence that brought a potential benefit to the president’s extended family: renewal of a program offering permanent residence in the United States to affluent foreigners investing money in real estate projects here.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: A Chinese Giant Is on a Global Buying Spree. Who’s Behind It?
articles.snippet: The HNA Group was transformed into a global powerhouse through an array of acquisitions and investments that were supported by Chinese state banks.
articles.abstract: The HNA Group was transformed into a global powerhouse through an array of acquisitions and investments that were supported by Chinese state banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his first state visit to Britain, President Xi Jinping of China heralded the great economic opportunities between the two countries, in energy, infrastructure and finance. He finished off the late 2015 trip at Manchester Airport, unveiling a new direct flight to Beijing on the Chinese carrier Hainan Airlines.

articles.headline: New Veterans Affairs Chief: A Hands-On, Risk-Taking ‘Standout’
articles.snippet: David Shulkin, 57, is a decisive leader and tireless student of efficiency who is among the “high priests” of patient-centered care, friends and former colleagues say.
articles.abstract: David Shulkin, 57, is a decisive leader and tireless student of efficiency who is among the “high priests” of patient-centered care, friends and former colleagues say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A gray-haired Vietnam veteran sat rustling on the paper of an examining table at the small veterans clinic in Grants Pass, Ore., on a recent afternoon when his doctor for the day appeared on a screen in front of him, wearing a white lab coat and bulbous headphones.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: ‘American Idol’ Is Coming Back to Television
articles.snippet: ABC announced that it would revive the old Fox hit, which was canceled because of falling ratings, sometime during the 2017-18 television season.
articles.abstract: ABC announced that it would revive the old Fox hit, which was canceled because of falling ratings, sometime during the 2017-18 television season.

articles.headline: South Korea Elects Moon Jae-in, Who Backs Talks With North, as President
articles.snippet: The victory of Mr. Moon, a liberal, could open a rift with the United States over how to best contain North Korea’s nuclear arsenal.
articles.abstract: The victory of Mr. Moon, a liberal, could open a rift with the United States over how to best contain North Korea’s nuclear arsenal.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea elected Moon Jae-in, a human rights lawyer who favors dialogue with North Korea, as president on Tuesday, returning the nation’s liberals to power after nearly a decade in the political wilderness and setting up a potential rift with the United States over the North’s nuclear weapons program.
